publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: IS he then taken?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: And brought back even now sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He was not in disgrace?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: No man more lov'd,
Nor more deserv'd it, being the onely man.
That durst be honest in this Court.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Indeed
We have heard abroad sir, that the State hath suffered,
A great change, since the countesse death.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: It hath sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My five yeares absence, hath kept me a stranger
So much to all the occurrents of my Country,
As you shall bind me for some short relation
To make me understand the present times.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I must begin then with a war was made
And seven yeares with all cruelty continued
Upon our Flanders by the Duke of Brabant,
The cause grew thus: during our Earles minority,
Woolfort, (who now usurps) was employed thither
To treat about a match betweene our Earle
And the daughter and Heire of Brabant: during which treaty
The Brabander pretends, this daughter was
Stolne from his Court, by practice of our State,
Though we are all confirm'd, 'twas a sought quarrell
To lay an unjust gripe upon this Earledome,
It being here beleev'd the Duke of Brabant
Had no such losse. This war upon't proclaim'd,
Our Earle, being then a Child, although his Father
Good Gerrard liv'd, yet in respect he was
Chosen by the Countesse favour, for her Husband
And but a Gentleman, and Floriz holding
His right unto this Country from his Mother,
The State thought fit in this defensive war,
Woolfort being then the only man of marke,
To make him Generall.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Which place we have heard
He did discharge with honour.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I, so long,
And with so blest successes, that the Brabander
Was forc't (his treasures wasted, and the choyce
Of his best men of Armes tyr'd, or cut off)
To leave the field, and sound a base retreat
Back to his Countrey: but so broken both
In minde and meanes, er'e to make head againe,
That hitherto he sitts downe by his losse,
Not daring, or for honour, or revenge
Againe to tempt his fortune. But this Victory
More broke our State, and made a deeper hurt
In Flanders, then the greatest overthrow
She ever receiv'd: For Woolfort, now beholding
Himselfe, and actions in the flattering glasse
Of selfe-deservings, and that cherish't by
The strong assurance of his power, for then
All Captaines of the Army, were his creatures,
The common Souldier too at his devotion,
Made so by full indulgence to their rapines
And secret bounties, this strength too well knowne
And what it could effect, soone put in practice,
As furtherd by the child-hood of the Earle
And their improvidence, that might have peirc't
The heart of his designes, gave him occasion
To sieze the whole, and in that plight you find it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, I receive the knowledge of thus much
As a choyce favour from you

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Onely I must add
Bruges holds out.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Whether sir, I am going
For there last night I had a ship put in,
And my horse waits me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I wish you a good journey.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: What? Hubert stealing from me? who disarm'd him,
It was more then I commanded; take your sword,
I am best guarded with it in your hand,
I have seene you use it nobly.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: And will turne it
On mine owne bosom, ere it shall be drawne
Vnworthily or rudely.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Would you leave me
Without a farwell Hubert? fly a friend
Vnwearied in his study to advance you?
What have I ev'r possessed which was not yours?
Or either did not court you to command it?
Who ever yet arriv'd to any grace,
Reward or trust from me, but his approaches
Wereby your faire reports of him prefer'd?
And what is more I made my selfe your Servant,
In making you the Master of those secrets
Which not the rack of conscience could draw from me,
Nor I, when I askt mercy, trust my prayers with;
Yet after these assurances of love,
These tyes and bonds of freindship, to forsake me,
Forsake me as an enemie? come you must
Give me a reason.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, and so I will,
If I may do't in privat: and you heare it.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: All leave the roome: you have your will, set downe
And use the liberty of our first friendship.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Friendship? when you prov'd Traitor first, that vanish'd
Nor do I owe you any thought, but hate,
I know my flight hath forfeited my head;
And so I may make you first understand
What a strange monster you have made your selfe,
I welcome it.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: To me this is strange language.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: To you? why what are you?

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Your Prince and Master,
The Earle of Flaunders.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: By a proper title,
Rais'd to it by cunning circumvention, force,
Blood, and proscriptions.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: And in all this wisedome;
Had I not reason? when by Gerrards plotts
I should haue first been call'd to a strict accop
How, and which way I had consum'd that masse
Of money, as they terme it in the warr,
Who underhand, had by his Ministers
Detracted my great action, made my faith
And loyalty so suspected in which failing
He sought my life by practice.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: With what fore-head,
Do you speake this to me? who (as I know't)
Must, and will say 'tis false,

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: My guard there.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, you bad me sit, & promis'd you would heare
Which I now say you shall, not a sound more,
For I that am contemner of mine owne,
Am Master of your life; then heer's a Sword
Betweene you, and all aydes Sir, though you blind
The credulous beast, the multitude, you passe not
These grosse untruthes on me.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: How? grosse untruthes.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I, and it is favourable language,
They had bin in a meane man lyes, and foule ones.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: You take strange licence.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Yes, were not those rumours
Of being called unto your answers, spread
By your owne followers; and weake Gerrard wrought
(But by your cunnig practise) to be beleeve
That you were dangerous; yet not to be
Punish'd by any formall course of law,
But first to be made sure, and have your crimes
Layd open after, which your queint traine taking
You fled unto the Campe, and there crav'd humbly
Protection for your innocent life, and that,
Since you had scap'd the fury of the warr,
You might not fall by treason, and for proofe,
You did not for your owne ends make this danger;
Some that had been before, by you subornd,
Came forth and tooke their oathes they had been hir'd
By Gerrard to your murther. This once heard,
And easily beleev'd, th'inraged Souldier
Seeing no further then the outward man,
Snatch'd hastily his Armes, ran to the Court,
Kill'd all that made resistance, cut in pieces
Such as were Servants, or thought friends to Gerrard,
Vowing the like to him.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Will you yet end?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Which he foreseeing, with his Sonne, the Earle,
Forsooke the Citty; and by secret wayes
As you give out, and we would gladly have it,
Escap'd their fury: though 'tis more then fear'd
They fell among the rest; Nor stand you there
To let us onely mourne, the impious meanes
By which you got it, but your cruelties since
So farr transcend your former bloody ills,
As if compar'd, they onely would appeare
Essayes of mischiefe; do not stop your eares,
More are behind yet.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: O repeat them not,
'Tis hell to heare them nam'd.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You should have thought,
That hell would be your punishment when you did them,
A Prince, in nothing but your princely lusts,
And boundlesse rapines.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: No more I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Who was the Lord of house or land, that stood
Within the prospect of your coveteous eye?

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: You are in this to me a greater Tyrant,
Then ere I was to any.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I end thus
The generall griefe, now to my private wrong;
The losse of Gerrards daughter Jaqueline:
The hop'd for partner of my lawfull bed,
Your cruelty hath frighted from mine armes;
And her, I now was wandring to recouer.
Thinke you that I had reason now to leave you,
When you are growne so justly odious,
That ev'n my stay here with your grace and favour,
Makes my life ircksome? here surely take it,
And do me but this fruite of all your frendship,
That I may dye by you, and not your hang-man.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Oh Hubert, these your wordes and reasons have
As well drawne drops of blood from my griev'd hart,
As these teares from mine eyes;
Despise them not
By all that's sacred, I am serious Hubert,
You now have made me sensible, what furyes,
Whips, hangmen, and tormentors a bad man
Do's ever beare about him: let the good
That you this day have done, be ever numberd,
The first of your best actions;
Can you think,
Where Floriz is or Gerrard, or your love,
Or any else, or all that are proscrib'd?
I will resigne, what I usurpe, or have
Unjustly forc'd; the dayes I have to live
Are too too few to make them satisfaction
With any penitence: yet I vow to practise
All of a man.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: O that your hart and tongue
Did not now differ!

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: By my griefes they do not
Nake the good paines to search them out; 'tis worth it,
You have made cleane a Leper: trust me you have,
And made me once more fit for the society,
I hope of good men.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, do not abuse
My aptnesse to beleeve.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Suspect not you
A faith that's built upon so true a sorrow,
Make your owne safetyes: aske them all the ties
Humanity can give, Hemskirick too shall
Along with you to this so wish'd discovery,
And in my name profess all that you promise;
And I will give you this helpe to't: I have
Of late receiv'd certaine intelligence,
That some of them are in or about Bruges
To be found out: which I did then interpret,
The cause of that Townes standing out against me;
But now am glad, it may direct your purpose
Of giving them their safety, and mee peace.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.p: Be constant to your goodnesse, & you have it. Ex.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: T'is much that you deliver of this Goswin.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: But short of what I could, yet have the Country
Confirmd it true, and by a generall oath,
And not a man hazard his credit in it:
He beares himselfe with such a confidence
As if he were the Master of the Sea;
And not a winde upon the Sailers compasse,
But from one part or other, was his factor,
To bring him in the best commodities,
Merchant e're venturd for:
'Tis strange,
And yet;
This do's in him deserve the least of wonder,
Compared with other his peculiar fashions,
Which all admire: he's young, and rich, at least
Thus far reputed so, that since he liv'd
In Bruges, there was never brought to harbour
So rich a Bottome, but his bill would passe
Unquestion'd for her lading.

sp.speaker: 3 Mer.
sp.l: Yet he still
Continues a good man.

sp.speaker: 2 Mer.
sp.l: So good, that but
To doubt him, would be held an injury
Or rather malice, with the best that traffique;
But this is nothing, a great stocke, and fortune,
Crowning his judgement in his undertakings
May keep him upright that way: But that wealth
Should want the power to make him dote on it,
Or youth teach him to wrong it, best commends
His constant temper; for his outward habit
'Tis sutable to his present course of life:
His table furnish'd well, but not with dainties
That please the appetite only for their rarenesse,
Or the deare price: nor given to wine or women,
Beyond his health, or warrant of a man,
I meane a good one: and so loves his state
He will not hazard it at play; nor lend
Upon the assurance of a well-pen'd Letter,
Although a challenge second the denyall
From such as make th'opinion of their valour
Their meanes of feeding.

sp.speaker: 1 Mer.
sp.l: These are wayes to thrive,
And the meanes not curs'd.

sp.speaker: 2 Mer.
sp.l: What follows this,
Makes many Venturers with him, in their wishes,
For his prosperity: for when desert
Or reason leads him to be liberall,
His noble mind and ready hand contend
Which can add most to his free curtesies,
Or in their worth, or speed to make them so.
Is there a Virgin of good fame wants dowre?
He is a father to her; or a Souldier
That in his Countreyes service, from the warre
Hath brought him only scars, and want? his house
Receives him, and relieves him, with that care
As if what he posses'd had been laid up
For such good uses, and he steward of it.
But I should loose my selfe to speake him further
And stale in my relation, the much good
You may be witnesse of, if your remove
From Brugis, be not speedy.

sp.speaker: 1 Mer.
sp.l: This report
I do assure you will not hasten it,
Nor would I wish a better man to deale with
For what I am to part with.

sp.speaker: 3 Mer.
sp.l: Never doubt it,
He is your man and ours, only I wish
His too much forwardnesse to embrace all bargains
Sucke him not in the end.

sp.speaker: 2 Mer.
sp.l: Have better hopes,
For my part I am confident; here he comes.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I take it at your own rates: your wine of Cyprus,
But for your Candy sugars, they have met
With such foule weather, and are priz'd so high
I cannot save in them.

sp.speaker: 4 Mer.
sp.l: I am unwilling
To seeke another Chap-man: make me offer
Of something near my price, that may assure me
You can deale for them.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I both can, and will,
But not with too much losse; your bill of lading
Speakes of two hundred chests, valued by you
At thirty thousand gilders. I will have them
At twenty eight; so, in the payment of
Three thousand sterling, you fall only in
Two hundred pound.

sp.speaker: 4 Mar.
sp.l: You know, they are so cheape.—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why looke you; I'le deale fairly, ther's in prison,
And at your suite, a Pirat, but unable
To make you satisfaction, and past hope
To live a weeke, if you should prosecute
What you can prove against him: set him free,
And you shall have your money to a Stiver,
And present payment.

sp.speaker: 4 Mar.
sp.l: This is above wonder,
A Merchant of your ranke, that have at Sea
So many Bottoms in the danger of
These water-Theeves, should be a meanes to save 'em
It more importing you for your owne safety
To be at charge to scoure the Sea of them
Then stay the sword of Justice, that is ready
To fall on one so conscious of his guilt
That he dares not deny it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You mistake me,
If you thinke I would cherish in this Captaine
The wrong he did to you, or any man;
I was lately with him, (having first, from others
True testimony been assured, a man
Of more desert never put from the shore)
I read his letters of Mart from this State granted
For the recovery of such losses, as
He had receiv'd in Spain, 'twas that he aim'd at,
Not at three tuns of wine, bisket, or beefe,
Which his necessity made him take from you.
If he had pillag'd you neare, or sunke your ship,
Or thrown your men o'r-boord, then he deserv'd
The Lawes extreamest rigour: But since want
Of what he could not live without, compel'd him
To that he did (which yet our State calls death)
I pitty his misfortune; and to worke you
To some compassion of them, I come up
To your own price: save him, the goods are mine;
If not, seeke else-where, I'le not deale for them.

sp.speaker: 4 Mar.
sp.l: Well Sir, for your love, I will once be lead
To change my purpose.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For your profit rather.

sp.speaker: 4 Mar.
sp.l: I'le presently make meanes for his discharge,
Till when, I leave you.

sp.speaker: 2 Mar.
sp.l: What do you thinke of this?

sp.speaker: 1 Mar.
sp.l: As of a deed of noble pitty: guided
By a strong judgement.

sp.speaker: 2 Mar.
sp.l: Save you Master Goswin.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Good day to all.

sp.speaker: 2 Mar.
sp.l: We bring you the refusall
Of more Commodities.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Are you the owners
Of the ship that lastnight put into the Harbour?

sp.speaker: 1 Mar.
sp.l: Both of the Ship, and lading.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What's the fraught?

sp.speaker: 3 Mar.
sp.l: And cloath of Gold brought from Camball.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Rich lading,
For which I were your Chapman, but I am
Already out of cash.

sp.speaker: 1 Mar.
sp.l: I'le give you day
For the moiety of all.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How long?

sp.speaker: 3 Mer.
sp.l: Sixe moneths.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis a faire offer: which (if we agree
About the prizes) I, with thanks accept of,
And will make present payment of the rest;
Some two hours hence I'le come aboord.

sp.speaker: 1 Mer.
sp.l: The Gunner shall speake you welcome.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I'le not faile,

sp.speaker: 3 Mer.
sp.l: Good morrow. Exit Merch.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Heaven grant my Ships a safe returne, before
The day of this great payment: as they are
Expected three moneths sooner: and my credite
Stands good with all the world. Enter Gerrard.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Blesse my good Master,
The prayers of your poor Beads-man ever shall
Be sent up for you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: God 'a mercy Clause,
Ther's something to put thee in minde hereafter
To thinke of me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: May he that gave it you
Reward you for it, with encrease, good Master.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I thrive the better for thy prayers.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I hope so.
This three yeares have I fed upon your bounties,
And by the fire of your blest charity warm'd me,
And yet, good Master, pardon me, that must,
Though I have now receiv'd your almes, presume
To make one sute more to you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What is't Clause?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Yet do not think me impudent I beseech you,
Since hitherto your charity hath prevented
My begging your reliefe, 'tis not for money
Nor cloaths (good Master) but your good word for me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That thou shalt have, Clause, for I think thee honest.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To morrow then (dear Mr.) take the trouble
Of walking early unto Beggars Bush,
And as you see me, among others (Brethren
In my affliction) when you are demanded
Which you like best among us, point out me,
And then passe by, as if you knew me not.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But what will that advantage thee?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O much Sir,
'Twill give me the preheminence of the rest,
Make me a King among 'em, and protect me,
From all abuse, such as are stronger, might
Offer my age; Sir, at your better leizure
I will informe you further of the good
It may do to me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Troth thou mak'st me wonder;
Have you a King and Common-wealth among you?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We have, & there are States are governd worse.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ambition among Beggars?

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.l: Many great ones
Would part with halfe their States, to have the place,
And credit to beg in the first file, Master:
But shall I be so much bound to your furtherance
In my Petition?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That thou shalt not misse of,
Nor any worldly cane make me forget it,
I will be early there.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Heaven blesse my Master. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Higgen, Ferret, Prig, Clause, Jaculine, Snap, Gynkes, and other Beggars.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: COme Princes of the ragged regiment,
You 'o the blood, Prig my most upright Lord,
And these (what name or title, e're they beare)
Jarkman, or Patrico, Cranke, or Clapperdudgeon.
Frater, or Abram-man; I speake to all
That stand in faire Election for the title
Of King of Beggars, with the command adjoyning,
Higgen, your Orator, in this Inter-regnum,
That whilom was your Dommerer, doth beseech you
All to stand faire, and put your selves in ranke,
That the first Commer, may at his first view
Make a free choise, to say up the question.

sp.speaker: Fer. Pr.
sp.l: 'Tis done Lord Higgen.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Thankes to Prince Prig, Prince Ferret.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Well, pray my Masters all, Ferret be chosen
Ye'ar like to have a mercifull mild Prince of me.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: A very tyrant, I, an arrant tyrant.
If e're I come to reigne; therefore looke to't,
Except you do provide me hum enough
And Lour to bouze with: I must have my Capons
And Turkeys brought me in, with my green Geese,
And Ducklings i'th season: fine fat chickens,
Or if you chance where an eye of tame Phesants
Or Partridges are kept, see they be mine,
Or straight I seize on all your priviledge,
Places, revenues, offices, as forfeit,
Call in your crutches, wooden legs, false bellyes,
Forc'd eyes and teeth, with your dead arms; not leave you
A durty clout to beg with o' your heads,
Or an old rag with Butter, Frankinsence,
Brimstone and Rozen, birdlime, blood, and creame,
To make you an old sore; not so much sope
As you may fome with i'th Falling-sicknesse;
The very bag you beare, and the brown dish
Shall be escheated. All your daintiest dells too
I will deflowr, and take your dearest Doxyes
From your warme sides; and then some one cold night
I'le watch you what olde barne you goe to roost in,
And there I'le smoother you all i'th musty hay.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: This is tyrant-like indeed: But what would Ginkes
Or Clause be here, if either of them should raigne?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Best aske an asse, if he were made a Camell,
What he would be; or a dog, and he were a Lyon.

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: I care not what you are, Sirs, I shall be
A Begger, still, I am sure, find my selfe there.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: O here a Judge comes.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Cry, a Judge, a Judge.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What aile you Sirs? what means this out cry?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Master
A sort of poor soules met: Gods fools, good Master,
Have had some little variance amongst our selves
Who should be honestest of us; and which lives
Uprightest in his call: Now, 'cause we thought
We ne're should gree on't our selves, because
Indeed 'tis hard to say: we all dissolv'd, to put it
To whom that should come next, and that's your Mastership,
Who, I hope, will termine it as your mind serves you,
Right, and no otherwise we aske it: which?
Which does your Worship thinke is he? sweet Master
Looke over us all, and tell us; we are seven of us,
Like to the seven wise Masters, or the Planets.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I should judge this the man with the grave beard,
And if he be not—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Blesse you, good Master, blesse you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I would he were: there's something too, amongst you
To keep you all honest. Exit

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: King of heaven goe with you.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Now good reward him,
May he never want it, to comfort still the poor, in a good houre.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What is't? see: Snap ha's got it.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: A good crown, marry:

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: A crown of gold.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For our new King: good luck.

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: To the common treasury with it; if 't be gold,
Thither it must.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Spoke like a Patriot, Ferret—
King Clause. I bid God save thee first, first, Clause,
After this golden token of a crowne;
Wher's Oratour Higgen with his gratuling speech now,
In all our names?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here he is pumping for it.

sp.speaker: Gin.
sp.l: H' has cough'd the second time, 'tis but once more
And then it comes.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So, out with all: expect now—

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: That thou art chosen, venerable Clause,
Our King and Soveraign; Monarch o'th Maunders.
Thus we throw up our Nab-cheats, first for joy,
And then our filches; last, we clap our fambles,
Three subject signes, we do it without envy:
For who is he here did not wish thee chosen
Now thou art chosen? aske 'em: all will say so,
Nay swear't: 'tis for the King, but let that passe;
When last in conference at the bouzing ken
This other day we sate about our dead Prince
Of famous memory: (rest, goe with his rags:)
And that I saw thee at the tables end,
Rise mov'd, and gravely leaning on one Crutch,
Lift the other like a Scepter at my head,
I then presag'd thou shortly wouldst be King
And now thou art so: but what need presage,
To us, that might have read it, in thy beard,
As well, as he that chose thee? by that beard
Thou wert found out, and mark'd for Soveraignty.
O happy beard! but happier Prince, whose beard,
Was so remark'd, as marked out our Prince,
Not bating us a haire. Long may it grow,
And thick, and faire, that who lives under it,
May live as safe, as under Beggars Bush,
Of which this is the thing, that but the type.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Excellent, excellent oratour, forward good Higgen
Give him leave to spit: the fine, well-spoken Higgen.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: This is the beard, the bush, or bushy-beard,
Under whose gold and silver raigne 'twas said
So many ages since, we all should smile
On impositions, taxes, grievances,
Knots in a State, and whips unto a Subject,
Lye lurking in this Beard, but all hem'd out:
If now, the Beard be such, what is the Prince
That owes the Beard? a Father; no, a Grandfather;
Nay the great Grand-father of you his people.
He will not force away your hens, your bacon,
When you have ventur'd hard for't, nor take from you
The fattest of your puddings: under him
Each man shall eate his own stolne eggs, and butter,
In his owne shade, or sun-shine, and enjoy
His owne deare Dell, Doxy, or Mort, at night
In his own straw, with his owne shirt, or sheet,
That he hath filch'd that day, I, and possesse
What he can purchase, backe, or belly-cheats
To his own prop: he will have no purveyers
For Pigs, and poultry.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: That we must have, my learned Oratour,
It is our will, and every man to keep
In his own path and circuite.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Do you heare?
You must hereafter maund on your own pads he saies.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And what they get there, is their owne, besides
To give good words.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Do you marke? to cut bene whids,
That is the second Law.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And keepe a-foote
The humble, and the common phrase of begging,
Lest men discover us.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Yes; and cry sometimes,
To move compassion: Sir, there is a table,
That doth command all these things, and enjoyns 'em;
Be perfect in their crutches: their fain'd plaisters,
And their true pas-ports, with the ways to stammer,
And to be dumb, and deafe, and blind, and lame,
There, all the halting paces are set downe,
I'th learned language.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thither I refer them,
Those, you at leisure shall interpret to them,
We love no heapes of lawes, where few will serve.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: O gracious Prince, 'save ,'save the good K. Clause.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: A Song to crowne him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Set a Centinell out first.

sp.speaker: Sn.
sp.l: The word?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: A Cove comes, and fumbumbis to it.— Strike.

lg.head: The SONG.
lg.l: CAst our Caps and cares away: this is Beggars Holli-day,
At the Crowning of our King, thus we ever dance & sing.
In the world looke out and see: where so happy a Prince as he?
Where the Nation live so free, and so merry as do we?
Be it peace, or be it war, here at liberty we are,
And enjoy our ease and rest; To the field we are not prest;
Nor are called into the Towne, to be troubled with the Gowne.
Hang all Offices we cry, and the Magistrate too, by;
When the Subsidies encreast, we are not a penny ceast.
Nor will any goe to law, with the Beggar for a straw.
All which happinesse he brags, he doth owe unto his rags.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: A Cove: Fumbumbis.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: To your postures; arme:

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Yonder's the Towne: I see it.

sp.speaker: Hemsk.
sp.l: Ther's our danger
Indeed afore us, if our shadows save not.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Blesse your good Worships:

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: One small piece of money.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Amongst us all poore wretches:

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Blinde, and lame,

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: For his sake that gives all.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Pittifull Worships;

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: One little doyt.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: King, by your leave, where are you?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To buy a litle bread,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: To feed so many
Mouths, as will ever pray for you.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Here be seven of us.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Seven, good Master, ô remember seven,
Seven blessings.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Remember, gentle Worship.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'Gainst seven deadly sins,

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And seven sleepers.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: If they be hard of heart, and will give nothing—
Alas, we had not a charity this three dayes.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Ther's amongst you all?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Heaven reward you.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Lord, reward you?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The Prince of pitty blesse thee.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Do I see? or is't my fancy that would have it so?
Ha? 'tis her face: come hither Maid.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What ha', you
Bells for my squirrell? I ha' giv'n Bun meat,
You do not love me, do you? catch me a butterfly,
And I'le love you againe; when? can you tell?
Peace, we go a birding: I shall have a fine thing.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Her voyce too sayes the same; but for my head
I would not that her manners, were so chang'd,
Heare me thou honest fellow; what's this Mayden,
That lives amongst you here?

sp.speaker: Gincks.
sp.l: Ao, ao, ao, ao.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: How? nothing but signes?

sp.speaker: Gin.
sp.l: Ao, ao, ao, ao.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This strange,
I would saine have it her, but not her thus.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: He is de-de-de-de-de-de-deafe, and du-du-dude— dumb Sir.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Slid they did all speak plain ev'n now me thought
Do'st thou know this same Maid?

sp.speaker: Sn.
sp.l: Why, why, why, why, which, gu, gu, gu, gu, Gods foole
She was bo-bo-bo-bo-borne at the barne younder,
By-be-be-be-be-Beggars Bush-bo-bo-Bush
Her name is, My-my-my-my-my-match: so was her Mo-mo-mo-Mothers too-too

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I understand no word she sayes; how long
Has she been here?

sp.speaker: Sn.
sp.p: Lo-lo-long enough to be ni-ni-nigled: and she ha' go-go-go-good luck,

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I must be better inform'd, then by this way.
Here was another face too, that I mark'd
O the old mans: but they are vanish'd all
Most sodainly: I will come here againe,
O, that I were so happy, as to finde it,
What I yet hope? it is put on.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What meane you Sir,
To stay there with that stammerer?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Farewell friend,—
It will be worth returne, to search: Come,
Protect us our disguize now, pre'thee Hemskirck
If we be taken, how do'st thou imagine
This Towne will use us, that hath stood so long
Out, against Woolfort?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Ev'n to hang us forth
Upon their walls a sunning, to make Crowes meate,
If I were not assur'd 'o the Burgomaster,
And had a pretty skuys, to see a niece there,
I should scarce venture.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Come 'tis now too late
To looke back at the ports: good luck, and enter. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Still blow'st thou there? and from all other parts,
Do all my Agents sleepe? that nothing comes?
Ther's a conspiracy of windes, and servants:
If not of Elements, to ha' me breake;
What should I thinke unlesse the Seas, and Sandes
Had swallow'd up my ships? or fire had spoyl'd
My ware-houses? or death devour'd my Facto
I must ha' had some returnes;

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: 'Saue you Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Save you.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: No newes, yet 'o your Ships?

sp.speaker: o.
sp.l: Not any yet Sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: 'Tis strange.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis true Sir: what a voyce was here now?
This was one passing bell, a thousand ravens
Sung in that man now, to presage my ruines.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.p: Goswin, good day, these winds, are very constant.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: They are so Sir; to hurt—

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: Ha? you had no letters,
Lately from England, nor from Denmark?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: This winde brings them; nor no newes over land,
Through Spaine, from the Straights?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Not any.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: I am sorry Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: They talke me downe: and as 'tis said, of Vultures
They sent a feild fought, and do smell the carkasses
By many hundred miles: So do these, my wracks
At greater distances: why thy will heaven
Come on, and be: yet if thou please, preserve me;
But in my owne adventure, here at home,
Of my chast love, to keep me worthy of her,
It shall be put in scale against all ill fortunes:
I am not broken yet: nor should I fall,
Me thinkes with lesse then that, that ruines all. Exit

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter. Van-donck. Hubert. Hemskirck. and Margaret. Boores.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Captaine you are welcome; so is this your friend
Most safely welcome, though our Towne stand out
Against your Master; you shall finde good quarter:
The troth is, we not love him: Meg: some wine,
Let's talke a little treason, If we can
Talk treason, gain' the Traitors; by your leave, Gentlemen
We here in Brugis, thinke he do's usurpe,
And therefore I am bold with him.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, your boldnesse,
Happely becomes your mouth, but not our eares,
While we are his servants; And as we come here,
Not to aske questions, walke forth on your walls;
Visit your courtes of guard, view your Munition,
Aske of your corne-provisions, nor enquire
Into the least, as spies upon your strengthes,
So let's entreate, we may receive from you
Nothing in passage or discourse, but what
We may with gladnesse, and our honesties here,
And that shall seale our welcome.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Good: let's drinke then,

sp.speaker: Mage:
sp.l: fill out, I keep mine old pearle still Captaine.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I hang fast man.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Old Iewels, commend their keeper, Sir.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Heer's to you with a hart, my Captaines friend,
With a good heart, and if this make us speake
Bold words, anon: 'tis all under the Rose
Forgotten: drowne all memory, when we drinke

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: 'Tis freely spoken noble Burgomaster,
I'le do you right.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Nay Sir mine heire Van-donck,
Is a true Statesmen.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Fill my Captaines cup there, ô that your Master Woolfort.
Had been an honest man.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Under the Rose.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Heer's to you Marget.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Welcom; welcom Captaine.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Well said my pearle still,

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Well said, my pearl still,

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: And how does my Niece?
Almost a woman; I thinke? This friend of mine,
I drew along with me, through so much hazard,
Only to see her: she was my errand.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: I, a kinde Uncle you are (fill him his glasse)
That in seven yeares, could not find leizure.—

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No,
It's not so much.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: I'le bate you nev'r an houre on't,
I was before the Brabander gan his war,
For moone-shine, i'th water there, his daughter
That never was lost: yet you could not finde time
To see a Kinswoman: But shee is worth the seeing Sir.
Now you are come, you aske if she were a woman?
Shee is a woman Sir; fetch her forth Margee. Exit Marg.
And a fine woman, and has Suitors.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: How?
What Suitors are they.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Bachellors: young Burgers:
And one, a gallant, the young Prince of Merchants,
We call him here, in Bruges.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: How? a Merchant?
I thought Van-doncke, you had understood me better,
And my Niece too, so trusted to you by me:
Then t'admit of such in name of Suitors.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Such? he is such a such, as were she mine
I'de give him thirty thousand crownes with her.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.p: But the same things Sir, fit not you and me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Why, give's some wine, then; This will fit us all:
Here's to you still, my Captains friend: All out:
And still, would Woolfort were an honest man,
Under the Rose, I speake it: but this Merchant
Is a brave boy: he lives so, i'the towne here,
We know not what to thinke on him: At sometimes
We feare he will be Bankrupt; he do's stretch
Tenter his credite so; embraces all,
And too't, the winds have been contrary, long.
But then, if he should have all his returnes,
We thinke he would be a King, and are halfe sure on't.
Your Master is a Traytor, for all this
Under the Rose: here's to you; and usurps
The Earldome from a better man.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I marry Sir,
Where is that man?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Nay soft: and I could tell you
'Tis ten to one I would not: here's my hand,
I love not Woolfort: sit you still, with that:
Here comes my Captaine againe, and his fine Niece,
And ther's my Merchant: view him well, fill wine here.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You must not only know me for your Uncle,
Now, but obey me; you, goe cast your selfe
Away, upon a dunghill here? a Merchant?
A petty fellow? one that makes this trade
With oathes and perjuries?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What is that you say Sir?
If it be me you speake of; as your eye
Seemes to direct: I wish you would speake to me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Sir, I do say, she is no Merchandize,
Will that suffice you?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Merchandize good Sir,
Though ye be Kinsman to her: take no leave thence
To use me with contempt: I ever thought
Your Niece above all price.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: And do so still, Sir,
I assure you, her rate's at more then you are worth.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You do not know, what a Gentleman's worth sir,
Nor can you value him.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Well said Merchant.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Nay,
Let him alone, and ply your matter.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: A Genntleman?
What, o' the wool-pack? or the Sugar-chest?
Or lists of Velvet? which is't? pound, or yard,
You vent your Gentry by?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: O Hemskirke, fye.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Come, do not mind 'em drink, he is no Woolfort,
Captaine, I advise you.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Alas, my pretty man,
I think't be angry, by its looke: Come hither,
Turne this way, a little: if it were the blood
Of Charlemaine, as 't may (for ought I know)
Be some good Botchers issue, here in Bruges.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Nay: I'me not certaine of that; of this I am,
If it once buy, and sell, its Gentry is gone.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ha, ha:

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You are angry, though ye laugh.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No, now 'tis pitty
Of your poor argument. Do not you, the Lords,
Of land (if you be any) sell the grasse,
The corne, the straw, the milke, the cheese?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: And butter:
Remember butter; doe not leave out butter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: The Beefs and Muttons that your grounds are stor'd with?
Swine, with the very mast, beside the woods?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No, for those sordid uses, we have Tenants,
Or else our Bayliffs.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Have not we Sir, Chap-men,
And Factors, then to answer these? your errour
Fetch'd from the Heralds A B C. and said over
With your Court faces, once an houre, shall never
Make me mistake my selfe. Do not your Lawyers
Sell all their practise, as your Priests their prayers?
What is not bought, and sold? The company
That you had last, what had you fort, y'faith?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You now grow sawcy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sure I have been bred
Still, with my honest liberty, and must use it.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Upon your equals, then.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sir, he that will
Provoke me first, doth make himselfe my equall.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Do ye heare? no more.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes Sir, this little, I pray you,
And't shall be aside, then after, as you please,
You appeare the Uncle, sir, to her I love,
More then mine eyes; and I have heard your scorns
With so much scoffing, and so much shame,
As each strive which is greater: But, beleeve me
I suck'd not in this patience with my milke.
Do not presume, because you see me young,
Or cast despights on my profession
For the civility and tamenesse of it.
A good man beares a contumely worse
Then he would do an injury. Proceed not
To my offence: wrong is not still successefull,
Indeed it is not: I would approach your Kins-woman
With all respect, done to your selfe and her.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Away Companion: handling her? take that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Nay, I do love no blows, sir, there's exchange.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Hold sir,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O murther.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Help, my Goswin.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Man.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Let 'em alone; my life for one.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Nay come
If you have will.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: None to offend you, I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He that had, thank himself: not hand her? yes Sir,
And claspe her, and embrace her; and (would she
Now goe with me) bear her through all her race,
Her Father, Brethren, and her Uncles, arme'd,
And all their Nephews, though they stood a wood
Of pikes, and wall of Canon: kisse me Gertrude,
Quake not, but kisse me.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Kisse him, girle, I bid you;
My Merchant royall; feare no Uncles: hang 'em,
Hang up all Uncles: Are we not in Bruges?
Under the Rose here?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: In this circle, Love,
Thou are as safe, as in a towre of brasse;
Let such as do wrong, feare.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: I, that's good,
Let Woolfort looke to that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sir, here she stands,
Your Niece, and my beloved. One of these titles
She must apply to; if unto the last,
Not all the anger can be sent unto her,
In frowne, or voyce, or other art, shall force her,
Had Hercules a hand in't: Come, my Joy,
Say thou art mine, aloud Love, and professe it.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Doe: and I drinke to it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Prethee say so, Love.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Twould take away the honour from my blushes:
Doe not you play the Tyrant, sweet: they speake it.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I thanke you Niece.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sir, thanke her for your life,
And fetch your sword within.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You insult too much
With your good fortune, Sir. Exit Florez.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: A brave cleare spirit;
Hemskirke, you were too blame: a civill habit
Oft covers a good man: and you may meete
In person of a Merchant, with a soule
As resolute, and free, and all wayes worthy,
As else in any file of man-kinde: pray you,
What meant you so to slight him?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: 'Tis done now,
Aske no more of it; I must suffer. Exit Hemskirk.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This,
Is still the punishment of rashnesse, sorrow;
Well; I must to the woods, for nothing here
Will be got out. There, I may chance to learne
Somewhat to help my enquiries further.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Ha?
A Looking-glasse.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: How now, brave Burgo-master?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I love no Woolforts, and my names Vandoncke,

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Van-donck it's rather: Come, go sleep within.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Earle Florez is right heir, and this same Woolfort
Under the Rose I speake it.—

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Very hardly.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Usurpes: and a ranke Traitor, as ever breath'd,
And all that do uphold him. Let me goe,
No man shall hold me, that upholds him;
Doe you uphold him?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Then hold me up. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Sir, I presume, you have a sword of your owne,
That can so handle anothers.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Faith you may Sir.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: And ye have made me have so much better thoughts of you
As I am bound to call you forth.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For what Sir?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: To the repairing of mine honour, & hurt here.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Expresse your way.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: By fight, and speedily.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You have your will: Require you any more?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: That you be secret: and come single.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: As you are the Gentleman you would be thought.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Without the Conjuration: and I'le bring
Only my sword, which I will fit to yours,
I'le take his length within.

sp.speaker: Hem
sp.l: Your place now Sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: By the Sand-hills.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Sir, nearer to the woods,
If you thought so, were fitter.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: There, then.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: good.
Your time?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Twixt seven and eight.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You'l give me Sir
Cause to report you worthy of my Niece,
If you come, like your promise.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If I do not
Let no man think to call me unworthy first,
I'le doe't my selfe: and justly wish to want her.— Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.p: COme, English beer Hostess, English beer by'th belly

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: Start beer boy, stout & strong beer: so, sit downe Lads,
And drinke me upsey-Dutch:
Frollicke, and feare not.

div.stage: Enter Higgen like a Sow-gelder, singing.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Have ye any worke for the Sow-gelder, boa,
My horne goes to high to low, to high to low.
Have ye any Piggs, Calves, or Colts,
Have ye any Lambs in your holts
To cut for the Stone
Here comes a cunning one.
Have ye any braches to spade,
Or e're a faire maide
That would be a Nun,
Come kisse me, 'tis done.
Harke how my merry borne doth blow,
Too high too low, too high too low.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: O excellent! two-pence a piece boyes, two-pence a piece:
Give the boys some drink there. Piper, wet your whistle.
Canst tell me a way now, how to cut off my wives Concupiscence?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I'le sing ye a Song for't.

q.label: The Song.
q.l: And turn her again boy, again,
Then her disease no longer will raign.
And once a day swinge her again
If she stand all these paines
Her disease no longer will reign.

sp.speaker: 1 Bo.
sp.l: More excellent, more excellent, sweet Sow-gelder.

sp.speaker: 2 Bo.
sp.l: Three-pence a peice, three-pence a peice.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Will you heare a Song how the Divel was gelded?

sp.speaker: 3 Bo.
sp.l: I, I, lets heare the Divell roare, Sow-gelder.

sp.speaker: 1 Bo.
sp.l: Groats a piece, groats a piece, groats a piece,
There sweet Sow-gelder.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Will ye see any feates of activity,
Some sleight of hand, leigerdemaine? hey passe,
Presto, be gone there?

sp.speaker: 2 Bo.
sp.l: Sit downe Jugler.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Sirha, play you your art well; draw neer piper:
Looke you, my honest friends, you see my hands;
Plaine dealing is no Divel: lend me some money;
Twelve-pence a piece will serve.

sp.speaker: 1. 2. B.
sp.l: There, there.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: I thanke you,
Thanke ye heartily: when shall I pay ye?

sp.speaker: All B.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, by'th masse this was a fine trick.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: A merry sleight toy: but now I'le shew your Worships
A tricke indeed.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Marke him well now my Masters.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Here are three balls,
These balls shall be three bullets,
One, two, and three: ascentibus malentibus.
Presto, be gone: they are vanish'd: faire play Gentlemen,
Now these three, like 3. bullets, from your three noses
Will I plucke presently: feare not, no harme boyes,
Titere, tu patule.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Recubans sub jermine fagi.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: Ye pull too hard; ye pull too hard.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Stand faire then:
Silvertramtrim-tram.

sp.speaker: 3 B.
sp.l: Hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Prig
sp.l: Come aloft bullets three, with a whim-wham:
Have ye their moneys?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Oh rare Jugler.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: Oh admirable Jugler,

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: One tricke more yet;
Hey, come aloft: sa, sa, flim, flum, taradumbis?
East, west, north, south, now flye like Jacke with a bumbis.
Now all your money's gone: pray search your pockets.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Humh.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: He,

sp.speaker: 3 B.
sp.l: The Divell a penny's here.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: This was a rare tricke.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: But 'twould be a far rarer to restore it.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: I'le doe ye that too: looke upon me earnestly,
And move not any wayes your eyes from this place,
This button here: pow, whir, whiss, shake your pockets

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: by'th masse 'tis here againe boyes.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Rest ye merry;
My first tricke has paid me.

sp.speaker: All B.
sp.l: I, take it, take it,
And take some drinke too.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Not a drop now I thanke you;
Away, we are discoverd else. Exit.

sp.stage: Enter Gerrard like a blinde Aquavitae-man, and a boy singing the Song.

lg.l: BRing out your Cony-skins, faire maids to me,
And hold 'em faire that I may see;
Grey, blacke, and blew: for your smaller skins,
I'le give ye looking-glasses, pins.
And for your whole Coney, heer's ready ready money.
Come gentle Jone, do thou begin
With thy blacke, blacke, blacke Cony-skin.
And Mary then, and Jane will follow,
With their silver-hair'd skins, and their yellow.
The white Cony-skin, I will not lay by,
For though it be faint, tis faire to the eye,
The grey it is warme, but yet for my money,
Give me the bonny, bonny blacke Coney.
Come away faire maides, your skins will decay:
Come, and take money maids, put your ware away.
Cony-skins, Cony-skins, have ye any Cony-skins,
I have fine brace-lets, and fine silver pins.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Buy any brand wine, buy any brand wine?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Have ye any Cony-skins.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: My fine Canary-bird, ther's a cake for thy worship,

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Come, fill, fill, fill, fill suddenly: let's see Sir,
What's this?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: A penny Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Fill till't be six-pence,
And there's my pig.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: This is a counter Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: A counter? stay ye, what are these then?
O execrable Jugler! ô damn'd Jugler!
Look in your hose, hoa: this comes of looking forward.

sp.speaker: 3 B.
sp.l: Divell a Dunkirke! what a rogue's this Jugler,
This hey passe, repasse, h'as repast us sweetly.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: Doe ye call these tricks.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Have ye any ends of gold or silver.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: This fellow comes to mock us; gold or silver? cry copper.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Yes my good friend,
We have e'ne an end of all we have.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'tis well Sir,
You have the lesse to care for: gold and silver, Exit.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Have ye any old cloaks to sel, have ye any old clokes to sel. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Cloakes? looke about ye boyes: mine's gone.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: A— juggle 'em?
— o' their Prestoes: mine's gone too.

sp.speaker: 3 B.
sp.l: Here's mine yet.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Come, come, let's drink then: more brand wine.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: If e're I catch your Sow-gelder, by this hand I'le strip him;
Were ever fooles so ferkt? we have two cloakes yet,
And all our caps; the Divell take the flincher.

sp.speaker: All B.
sp.l: Yaw, yaw, yaw, yaw.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Good do'n my honest fellows,
You are merry here I see.

sp.speaker: 3 B.
sp.l: 'Tis all we have left Sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What hast thou? Aquavitae?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Fill out then,
And give these honest fellows round.

sp.speaker: All b.
sp.l: We thanke ye.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: May I speake a word in private to ye?

sp.speaker: All b.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I have a businesse for you, honest friends,
If you dare lend your help, shall get you crownes.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ha?
Lead me a little nearer, boy.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: What is't Sir?
If it be any thing to purchase money,
Which is our want, command us.

sp.speaker: Boors.
sp.l: All, all, all Sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You know the young spruce Merchant in Brugis.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: Who? Master Goswin?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: That: he owes me money,
And here in towne there is no stirring of him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Say ye so?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: This day, upon a sure appointment,
He meets me a mile hence, by the Chase side
Under the row of Okes, do you know it?

sp.speaker: All b.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Give 'em more drinke: there if you dare but venture
When I shall give the word to seize upon him,
Here's twenty pound.

sp.speaker: 3 Boy.
sp.l: Beware the Jugler.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: If he resist, downe with him, have no mercy.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.l: I warrrant you: wee'l hamper him.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: To discharge you,
I have a warrant here about me.

sp.speaker: 3 Boy.
sp.l: Her's our warrant,
This carries fire i'the tayle.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Away with me then,
The time draws on,
I must remove so insolent a Suitor,
And if he be so rich, make him pay ransome
Ere he see Bruges towres againe: thus wise men
Repaire the hurts they take by a disgrace,
And piece the Lyons skyn with the Foxes case.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I am glad I have heard this sport yet.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Ther's for thy drink; come pay the house within boyes,
And loose no time.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Away with all our hast too. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No winde blow faire yet? no returne of moneys?
Letters? nor any thing, to hold my hopes up?
Why then 'tis destin'd, that I fall, fall miserably,
My credite I was built on, sinking with me.
Thou boystrous North-wind, blowing my mis-fortunes,
And frosting all my hopes to cakes of coldnesse,
Yet stay thy fury: give the gentle South
Yet leave to court those sailes that bring me safety,
And you auspicious fires, bright twins in heaven
Daunce on the shrowds: he blows still, stubbornly,
And on his boystrous racke rides my sad ruine;
There is no help, there can be now no comfort,
To morrow with the Sun-set sets my credite.
Oh misery! thou curse of man, thou plague,
In the midst all our strength thou strik'st us;
My vertuous Love is toss'd too: all, what I have been,
No more hereafter to be seen then shadow;
To prison now? well, yet ther's this hope left me,
I may sinke fairely under this dayes venture
And so to morrow's cross'd, and all those curses:
Yet manly I'le invite my fate, base fortune
Shall never say, she has cut my throate in feare.
This is the place his challenge call'd me too,
And was a happy one at this time for me,
For let me fall before my foe i'the field,
And not at Bar, before my Creditors,
Ha's kept his word: now Sir, your swords tongue only
Loud as you dare, all other language—

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Well Sir,
You shall not be long troubled: draw.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis done Sir,
And now have at ye.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Now.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Betray'd to Villains?
Slaves ye shall buy me bravely,
And thou base coward.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now upon 'em bravely,
Conjure 'em soundly boyes.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Lay on still,
Down with that Gentleman rogue, swinge him to sirrup:
Retire Sir, and take breath: follow and take him,
Take all, 'tis lawfell prize.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: We yield.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Downe with 'em
Into the wood, and rifile 'em, tew 'em, swinge 'em,
Knocke me their braines into their breeches. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Boors.
sp.l: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What these men are I know not, nor for what cause
They should thus thrust themselves into my danger,
Can I imagine. But sure heavens hand was in't,
Nor why this coward knave should deale so basely
To eate me up with slaves: but heaven, I thanke thee,
I hope thou hast reserv'd me to an end
Fit for thy creature, and worthy of thine honour:
Would all my other dangers here had suffered,
With what a joyfull heart should I goe home then?
Wher now, heaven knows, like him that waits his sentence
Or heares his passing bell; but ther's my hope still.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Blessing upon you Master.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thanke ye; leave me,
For by my troth I have nothing now to give thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Indeed I do not aske Sir, only it grieves me
To see ye looke so sad; now goodnesse keepe ye
From troubles in your minde.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If I were troubled
What could thy comfort do? prethee Clause, leave me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Good Master be not angry; for what I say
Is out of true love to ye..

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I know thou lov'st me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Good Mr. blame that love then, if I prove so sawcy
To aske ye why ye are sad.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Most true, I am so,
And such a sadnesse I have got will sinke me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Heaven shield it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Faith thou must loose thy Master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I had rather loose my neck Sir: would I knew—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What would the knowledg do thee good, so miserable,
Thou canst not help thy selfe? when all my ways
Nor all the friends I have—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You do not know Sir,
What I can doe: cures sometimes, for mens cares
Flow, where they least expect 'em.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I know thou wouldst doe,
But fare-well Clause, and pray for thy poore Master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I will not leave ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I dare not leave ye,
And till ye beate me dead, I must not leave ye.
By what ye hold most pretious, by heavens goodnesse,
As your faire youth may prosper, good Sir tell me:
My minde beleeves yet something's in my power
May ease you of this trouble.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will tell thee
For a hundred thousand crownes upon my credit,
Taken up of Merchants to supply my traffiques,
The windes and weather envying of my fortune,
And no returne to help me off, yet shewing
To morrow, Clause, to morrow, which must come
In spron, thou shalt finde me poore, and broken.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I cannot blame your griefe Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now, what say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I say you should not shrinck, for he that gave ye,
Can give you more; his power can bring ye off Sir,
When friends and all forsake ye, yet he sees you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That's all my hope.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Hope still Sir, are you tide
Within the compasse of a day, good Master,
To pay this masse of money?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ev'n to morrow;
But why do I stand mocking of my misery?
Is't not enough the floods, and friends forget me?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Will no lesse serve?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What if it would?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your patience,
I do not aske to mock ye: 'tis a great sum,
A sum for mighty men to start, and stick at;
But not for honest: have ye no friends left ye,
None that have felt your bounty? worth this duty?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Duty? thou know'st it not.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It is a duty,
And as a duty, from those men have felt ye,
Should be return'd againe: I have gain'd by ye,
A daily almes these seven yearess you have showr'd me,
Will halfe supply your want.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why do'st thou foole me?
Can'st thou worke miracles?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To save my Master,
I can worke this.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou wilt make me angry with thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: For doing good?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What power hast thou?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Enquire not:
So I can do it, to preserve my Master;
Nay if it be three parts.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O that I had it,
But good Clause, talke no more, I feele thy charity,
As thou has felt mine: but alas!

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Distrust not.
'Tis that that quenches ye: pull up your spirit,
Your good, your honest, and your noble spirit;
For if the fortunes often thousand people
Can save ye, rest assur'd; you have forgot Sir,
The good ye did, which was the power you gave me;
Ye shall now know the King of Beggars treasure:
And let the windes blow as they please, the Seas roare,
Yet, here to morrow, you shall finde your harbour,
Here faile me not, for if I live I'le fit ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How faine I would believe thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: If I ly Master,
Believe no man hereafter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will trye thee,
But he knowes, that knowes all.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Know me to morrow,
And if I know not how to cure ye, kill me;
So passe in peace, my best, my worthiest Master. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Thus have I stolne away disguiz'd from Hemskirck
To try these people, for my heart yet tells me
Some of these Beggars, are the men I looke for
Appearing like my selfe, they have no reason
(Though my intent is faire, my maine end honest)
But to avoyde me narrowly, that face too,
That womans face, how neere it is: ô may it
But prove the same, and fortune how I'le blesse thee;
Thus, sure they cannot know me, or suspect me,
If to my habit I but change my nature;
As I must do; this is the wood they live in,
A place fit for concealement: where, 'till fortune
Crowne me with that I seeke, I'le live amongst 'em. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Higgen. Prig. Ferret. Gynks. and the rest of the Boores.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Come bring 'em out, for here we sit in justice:
Give to each one a cudgell, a good cudgell:
And now attend your sentence, that you are rogues,
And mischeivous base rascalls, (ther's the point now)
I take it, is confess'd.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Deny it if you dare knaves.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: We are Rogues Sir.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: To amplify the matter then rogues as ye are,
And lamb'd, ye shall be ere we leave ye.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And to the open handling of our justice,
Why did ye this upon the proper person
Of our good Master? were you drunk when you did it?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Yes indeed were we.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: You shall be beaten sober.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Was it for want you undertooke it?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: You shall be swing'd aboundantly.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And yet for all that,
You shall be poore rogues still.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Has not the Gentleman,
Pray marke this point Brother Prig, that noble Gentleman
Releiv'd ye often, found ye meanes to live by,
By imploying some at Sea, some here; some there;
According to your callings?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: 'Tis most true Sir.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Is not the man, an honest man?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Yes truly.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: A liberall Gentleman? and as ye are true rascalls
Tell me but this, have ye not been drunk, and often,
At his charge?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Often, often.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Ther's the point then,
They have cast themselves, brother Prig.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: A shrew'd point Brother.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Brother, proceed you now; the cause is open,
I am some what weary.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Can you do these things?
You most abhominable stincking Rascalls,
You turnip-eating Rogues.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: We are truly sorry.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Knock at your hard harts Rogues, and presently
Give us a signe you feele compunction,
Every man up with's cudgell, and on his neighbour
Bestow such almes, 'till we shall say sufficient,
For there your sentence lyes without partiality;
Either of head, or hide, Rogues, without sparing,
Or we shall take the paines to beat you dead else:
You shall know your doom.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: One, two, and three about it.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: That fellow in the blew, has true compunction,
He beates his fellowes bravely, oh, well struck boyes,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Up with that blew breech, now playes he the Divell,
So get ye home, drink small beere, and be honest;
Call in the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Do, bring him presently,
His cause I'le heare my selfe.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Prig. With all due reverence,
We do resigne Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now huffing Sir, what's your name?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What's that to you Sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It shall be ere we part.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: My name is Hemskirk,
I follow the Earle, which you shall feele.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: No threatning,
For we shall coole you Sir; why did'st thou basely
Attempt the murder of the Merchant Goswin?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What power hast thou to aske me?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I will know it.
Or flea thee till thy paine discover it.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: He did me wrong, base wrong.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: That cannot save ye,
Who sent ye hither? and what further villanies
Have ye in hand?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Why would'st thou know? what profit,
If I had any private way, could rise
Out of my knowledge, to do thee commodity?
Be sorry for what thou hast done, and make amends foole
I'le talke no further to thee: nor these rascalls.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tye him to that tree.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I have told you whom I follow.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: The Divell you should do, by your villanies,
Now he that has the best way, wring it from him.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I undertake it: turne him to the Sun boyes;
Give me a fine sharpe rush, will ye confesse yet?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Ye have rob'd me already, now you'le murder me

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Murder your nose a little: does your head purge Sir?
To it againe, 'twill do ye good.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Oh,
I cannot tell you any thing.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Proceed then.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Ther's maggots in your nose, I'le fetch em out Sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: O my head breakes.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The best thing for the rhewme Sir,
That falls into your worships eyes.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Speake then.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I know not what.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: It lyes in 's braine yet,
In lumps it lyes, I'le fetch it out the finest;
What pretty faces the foole makes? heigh!

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Hold,
Hold, and I'le tell ye all, looke in my doublet;
And there within the lining in a paper,
You shall finde all.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Go fetch that paper hither,
And let him loose for this time.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Good ev'n my honest friends.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Good ev'n good fellow.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: May a poore huntsman, with a merry hart,
A voyce shall make the forrest ring about him,
Get leave to live amongst ye? true as steele, boyes?
That knowes all chases, and can watch all howres,
And with my quarter staffe, though the Divell bid stand,
Deale such an almes, shall make him roare again?
Prick ye the fearefull hare through crosse wayes, sheepe walkes
And force the crafty Reimald climb the quiksetts;
Rouse ye the lofty Stag, and with my bell-horne,
Ring him a knell, that all the woods shall mourne him,
'Till in his funerall teares, he fall before me?
The Polcat, Marterne, and the rich skin'd Lucerne,
I know to chase, the Roe, the winde out-stripping
Isgrin himselfe, in all his bloody anger;
I can beate from the bay, and the wild Sounder
Single, and with my arm'd staffe, turne the Boare,
Spight of his fomy tushes, and thus strike him;
'Till he fall downe my feast.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: A goodly fellow.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: What mak'st thou here, ha?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We accept thy fellowship.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.p: Hemskirck, thou art not right I feare, I feare thee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here is the paper: and as he said we found it.

sp.speaker: Ger,
sp.l: Give me it, I shall make a shift yet, old as I am
To finde your knavery: you are sent here, Sirra
To discover certaine Gentlemen, a spy-knave
And if ye finde 'em, If not by perswasion
To bring 'em back, by poyson to dispatch 'em.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: By poyson, ha?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Here is an other, Hubert;
What is that Hubert Sir?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You may perceive there.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I may perceive a villany and a ranke one,
Was he joyn'd partner of thy knavery?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No.
He had an honest end, would I have had so,
Which makes him scape such cut throates.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So it seemes,
For here thou art commanded, when that Hubert
Has done his best and worthiest service, this way
To cut his throat, for here he's set downe dangerous.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This is most impious.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I am glad we have found ye,
Is not this true?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Yes? what are you the better;

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You shall perceive Sir, ere you get your fredome:
Take him aside, and friend, we take thee to us,
Into our company, thou dar'st be true unto us?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I, and obedient too?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: As you had bred me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Then take our hand: thou art now a servant to us,
Welcom him all.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Stand off, stand off: I'le do it,
We bid yee welcome three wayes; first for your person,
Which is a promising person, next for your quallity,
Which is a decent, and a gentle quality,
Last for the frequent meanes you have to feed us,
You can steale 'tis to be presum'd.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Yes, venson,
Or if I want—

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'Tis well you understand right,
And shall learne dayly: you can drink too?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Soundly.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And ye dare know a woman from a weathercock?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Yes, if I handle her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now sweare him.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: You are welcom Brother.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Welcom, welcom, welcom, but who shall have the keeping
Of this fellow?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Thank ye friends,
And I beseech ye, if you dare but trust me;
For if I have kept wilde doggs and beastes for wonder,
And made 'em tame too: give into my custody
This roaring rascall I shall hamper him,
With all his knacks and knaveryes, and I feare me
Discover yet a further villany in him;
O he smells ranck 'oth rascall.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Take him to thee,
But if he scape—

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Let me be ev'n hang'd for him,
Roome Sir, I'le tye ye to my leash.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: A way Rascall.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Be not so stubborne: I shall swindge ye soundly,
And ye play tricks with me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now sweare him.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I crowne thy nab, with a gag of benbouse,
And stall thee by the salmon into the clowes,
To mand on the pad, and strike all the cheates;
To mill from the Ruffmans, commision and states,
Twang dell's, i' the stiromell, and let the Quire Cuffin:
And Herman Beck strine, and trine to the Ruffin.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now interpret this unto him.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I powre on thy pate a pot of good ale,
And by the Rogues oth a Rogue thee install:
To beg on the way, to rob all thou meetes;
To steale from the hedge, both the shirt and the sheetes:
And lye with thy wench in the straw till she twang,
Let the Constable, Iustice, and Divell go hang.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So, now come in,
But ever have an eye Sir, to your prisoner.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: He must blinde both mine eyes, if he get from me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Go, get some victualls, and some drink, some good drink
For this day wee'le keep holly to good fortune,
Come and be frollick with us.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: ye are a stranger. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Indeed yae'r welcom: I have hard your scape,
And therefore give her leave, that onely loves you;
(Truely and dearely loves ye) give her joy leave,
To bid ye welcom: what 'ist makes you sad man?
Why do you looke so wilde? is 't I offend ye?
Be shrew my heart, not willingly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No Jertred.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Is't the delay of that ye 'long have look'd for,
A happy marriage? now I come to urge it:
Now when ye please to finish it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No newes yet?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Do you heare Sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Do you love me?

sp.speaker: Flo..
sp.l: Have I liv'd,
In all the happinesse fortune could seat me,
In all mens faire opinions?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I have provided
A Priest, that's ready for us.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: And can the Divell,
In one ten dayes, that Divell chance devour me?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Wee'le fly to what place you please.

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.l: No star prosperous?
All at a swoope?

sp.speaker: Ber:
sp.l: You do not love me Goswin?
You will not looke upon me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Can mens prayers
Shot up to heaven, with such a zeale as mine are,
Fall back like lazy mists, and never prosper?
Geyves, I must weare, and cold must be my comfort;
Darknesse, and want of meat; alas she weepes too,
Which is the top of all my sorrowes, Jertred.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No, no, you will not know me; my poore beauty,
Which has been worth your eyes.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: The time growes on still:
And like a tumbling wave, I see my ruine,
Come rolling over me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yet will ye know me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For a hundred thousand crownes.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yet will ye love me?
Tell me but how I have deserv'd your slighting.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For a hundred thousand crownes?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Farewell dissembler.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Of which I have scarce ten: ô how it starts me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: And may the next you love, hearing my ruine.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I had forgot my selfe, ô my best Gertrud,
Crowne of my joyes, and comforts.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: sweet what ayle ye?
I thought you had been vext with me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My minde wench,
My minde o're flow'd with sorrow, sunck my memory.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Am I not worthy of the knowledge of it?
And cannot I as well affect your sorrowes,
As your delights? you love no other woman?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No I protest.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You have no ships lost lately?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: None that I know of.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I hope you have spilt no blood: whose innocence
May lay this on your conscience.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Cleare, by heaven.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why should you be thus then?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Good Jertred, aske not,
Ev'n By the love you beare me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am obedient.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Go in my faire; I will not be long from ye,
Nor long I feare me with thee, At my returne
Despise me as you please.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: The good gods guide ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now for my selfe which is the least I hope for,
And when that failes, for mans worst fortune, pitty. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: WHy Gentlemen, 'tis but a week more I intreat you
But 7. short daies, I am not runnig from ye,
Nor, if you give me patience, is it possible
All my adventures faile; you have ships abroad,
Endure the beating both of winde, or weather:
I am sure 'twould vex your hearts, to be protested
Ye are all faire Merchants,

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: Yes, and must have faire play;
There is no lying here else, one howres failing
Failes us of all our friends, of all our credits:
For my part I would stay; but my wants tell me,
I must wrong others in't.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No mercy in ye?

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: 'Tis foolish to depend on others mercy:
Keepe your selfe right, and even, out your cloth Sir,
According to your calling: you have liv'd here
In Lordlike prodigality; high, and open,
And now ye finde what 'tis: the liberall spending
The summer of your youth, which you should gleane in,
And like the labouring Ant, make use and gaine of,
Has brought this bitter stormy winter on ye,
And now you cry.

sp.speaker: 3. Mer.
sp.l: Alas before your poverty,
We were no men, of no marke, no endeavour;
You stood alone, tooke up all trade, all business,
Running through your hands, scarce a sayle at Sea,
But loaden with your goods: we poore weak pedlers,
When by your leave, and much intreaty to it:
We could have stoage for a little cloth,
Or a few wines, put of and thanke your worship
Lord, how the world's chang'd with ye? now I hope Sir,
We shall have sea-roome

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is my misery,
Become my scorne too? have ye no humanity,
No part of men left? are all the bountyes in me
To you, and to the Towne; turn'd my reproaches?

sp.speaker: 4. Mer.
sp.l: Well, get your monyes ready: 'tis but 2. howres
We shall protest ye else, and sodainly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But two dayes.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: Not an howre, ye know the hazard. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How soone my light's put out: hard harted Bruges;
Within thy walls, may never honest Merchant
Venture his fortunes more: ô my poore wench too;

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Good fortune Master.

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.l: Thou mistak'st me Clause,
I am not worth thy blessing.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: Stil a sad man?
sp.stage: Enter Higgen. and Prig. like Porter.
sp.l: No beliefe gentle Master? come bring it in then,
And now believe your Beadesman.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is this certaine?
Or do'st thou work upon my troubled sence?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis gold Sir,
Take it and try it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Certainely 'tis treasure,
Can there be yet this blessing?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Cease your wonder,
You shall not sinke, for nev'r a sowst Flap-dragon:
For nere a pickell'd pilcher of 'em all Sir,
'Tis there your full summ, a hundred thousand crownes,
And good sweet Master, now Be merry: pay 'em
Pay the poore pelting knaves, that know no goodnesse:
And cheere your heart up handsomely.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Good Clause,
How cam'st thou by this mighty summ? if naughtily
I must not take it of thee, 'twill undo me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Feare not: you have it by as honest meanes
As though your father gave it: Sir, you know not
To what a masse, the little we get dayly,
Mounts in seven yeares; we beg it for heavens charity,
And to the same good, we are bound to render it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What great security?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Away with that Sir,
Were not ye more then all the men in Bruges;
And all the money in my thoughts—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But good Clause,
I may dye presently.

sp.speaker: Ger,
sp.l: Then this dyes with ye-
Pay when you can good Master, I'le no parchments,
Onely this charity I shall intreat ye,
Leave me this Ring.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Alas, it is to poore Clause.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis all I aske, and this with all, that when
I shall deliver this back, you shall grant me
Freely one poore petition.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: There I confesse it,
And may my faith forsake mee when I shun it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Away, your time drawes on. Take up the money
And follow this young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Farewell Clause,
And may thy honest memory live ever.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Heaven blesse ye and still keep ye, farewell Master.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I have lockt my youth up close enough for gadding
In an olde tree, and set watch over him.
Now for my Love, for sure this wench must be she,
She follows me; Come hither, pretty Minche.

sp.speaker: Jac,
sp.l: No, no, you'l kisse,

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: So I will.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Y'ded law?
How will ye kisse me, pray you?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Thus: soft as my loves lips.

sp.speaker: Jac.
