sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: What's your Fathers name?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: He's gone to heaven.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Is it not Gerrard, sweet?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I'le stay no longer,
My mother's an olde woman, and my Brother
Was drown'd at sea, with catching Cockles. O love:
O how my heart melts in me: how thou fir'st me!

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: 'Tis certain she: pray let me see your hand, sweet,

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No, no, you'l bite it.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sure I should know that Gymmall;

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: 'Tis certaine he: I had forgot my ring too.
O Hubert, Hubert.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Ha? me-thought she nam'd me—
Doe you know me, Chicke?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No indeed, I never saw ye,
But me-thinks you kisse finely.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Kisse againe then;
By heaven 'tis she.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O what a joy he brings me.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You are not Minche?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Yes pretty Gentleman,
And I must be married to morrow to a Capper.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Must ye my sweet, and doe's the Capper love ye?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes, yes, he'l give me pye, & look in mine eys thus:
Tis he: 'tis my deare Love; ô blest fortune.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: How fain she would conceal her selfe? yet shew it,
Will ye love me, and leave that man? I'le serve.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O I shall loose my selfe.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I'le waite upon ye,
And make ye dainty Nose-gayes.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And where will ye sticke 'em?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Here in bosome, and make a crown of Lillies
For your faire head.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And will ye love me, deed-law?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Call me to morrow then,
And we'l have brave chear, and goe to Church together:
Give you good ev'n Sir.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: But one word faire Minche.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I must be gone a milking.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Ye shall presently.
Did you never heare of a young Maid called Jaculine?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am discovered: hark in your eare, I'le tell ye;
You must not know me: kisse and be constant ever.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Heaven curse me else: tis she, and now I am certain
They are all here: now for my other project.— Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Floriz. 4. Merchants, Higgen, and Prig.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: Nay if it would do you courtesy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: None at all Sir;
Take it 'tis yours: ther's your ten thousand for ye,
Give in my Bills: your sixteene.

sp.speaker: 3. Mer.
sp.l: Pray be pleas'd Sir,
To make a further use.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: 3. Mer.
sp.l: What I have Sir,
You may command; pray let me be your Servant.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Put your hatts on: I care not for your courtisies,
They are most untimely don, and no truth in 'em.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: I have a frought of pepper.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Rot your pepper,
Shall I trust you againe? ther's your seven thousand.

sp.speaker: 4. Mer.
sp.l: Or if you want fine suger, 'tis but sending.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No, I can send to Barbary, those people
That never yet knew faith, have nobler freedoms:
These carry to Vanlock, and take my Bills in
To Peter Zuten these: bring back my Iewells;
Why are these peices?

sp.speaker: Saylor.
sp.l: Health to the noble Merchant,
The Susan is return'd.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Well?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Well, and rich Sir,
And now put in.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Heaven thou hast heard my prayers.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: The brave Rebecca too: bound from the straights,
With the next tide is ready to put after.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What newes o'th' fly-boate?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: If this winde hold till midnight,
She will be here, and wealthy, scap't fairely.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How, pre'thee Saylor?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Thus Sir, she had fight
Seven howers together, with six Turkish Gallyes,
And she fought bravely: but at length was borded:
And over lai'd with strength: when presently
Comes boring up the winde Captaine Van-donck,
That valiant Gentleman, you redeem'd from prison;
He knew the Boate, set in: and fought it bravely:
Beate all the Gallies off; sunk three, redeem'd her,
And as a service to ye, sent her home Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: An honest noble Captaine, and a thankfull;
Ther's for thy new's: go drink the Merchants health, Saylor

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: I thanke your bounty, and I'le do it to a doyt, Sir,

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: What miracles are powr'd upon this fellow?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: This ye are I hope my friends, I shall scape prison,
For all your cares to catch me.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer
sp.l: You may please Sir
To think of your poor servants in displeasure,
Whose all they have, goods, monyes, are at your service.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I thank you,
When I have need of you I shall forget you:
You are paid I hope.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We joy in your good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Come Sir, come take your ease you must go home
With mee, yonder is one weepes and howles.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Alas how does she?

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: She will be better soone I hope.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why soone sir?

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Why when you have her in your armes, this night,
My boy she is thy wife

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: With all my hart I take her.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: We have prepar'd, all thy friends will be there,
And all my Roomes shall smoake to see the revell;
Thou hast been wrong'd and no more shall my seruice,
Waite on the knaue her Vncle, I have hard all,
All his baites for my Boy, but thou shalt have her;
Hast thou dispatch't thy businesse?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Most.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: By the masse Boy,
Thou tumblest now in wealth, and I joy in it,
Thou art the best Boy, that Bruges ever nourish'd
Thou hast been sad, I'le cheere thee up with Sack,
And when thou art lusty I'le fling thee to thy Mistris.
Shee'l hug thee, sirha.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I long to see it,
I had forgot you: ther's for, you my friends:
You had but heavy burthens, commend my love
To my best love, all the love I have
To honest Clause, shortly I will thanke him better. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: By the masse a royall Merchant,
Gold by the handfull, here will be sport, soone Prig.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: It partly seemes so, and here will I be in a trice.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And I boy,
Away a pace we are look'd for.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Oh these bak'd meates,
Me thinkes I smell them hither.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Thy mouth waters. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I Must not,

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: Why? 'tis in thy power to do it, and in mine
To reward thee to thy wishes.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I dare not, nor I will not.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Gentle Huntsman,
Though thou hast kept me hard: though in thy duty,
Which is requir'd to do it, th' hast used me stubbornly;
I can forgive thee freely.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You the Earles servant.

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: I sweare I am neare as his owne thoughts to him;
Able to doe thee—

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Come, come, leave your prating.

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: If thou dar'st but try.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I thanke you hartily, you will be
The first man that will hang me, a sweet recompence,
I could do, but I do not say I will,
To any honest fellow that would thinke on't:
And be a benefactor.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: If it be not recompenc'd, and to thy owne desires,
If within these ten dayes I do not make thee—

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: What, a false knave?

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: Prethee, prethee conceive me rightly, any thing
Of profit or of place that may advance thee.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Why what a Goosecap would'st thou make me,
Do not I know that men in misery will promise
Any thing, more then their lives can reach at?

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: Beleeve me Huntsman,
There shall not one short sillable
That comes from me, passe
Without it's full performance.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Say you so Sir?
Have ye e're a good place for my quality.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: A thousand Chases, Forrests, Parks: I'le make thee
Chiefe ranger over all the games.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Presently.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This may provoke me: and yet to prove a knave too.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: 'Tis to prove honest: 'tis to do good service,
Service for him thou art sworn to, for thy Prince,
Then for thy selfe that good; what fool would live here,
Poore, and in misery, subject to all dangers,
Law, and lewd people can inflict, when bravely
And to himselfe he may be law, and credit?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Shall I believe thee?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: As that thou holdst most holy;

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Ye may play tricks.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Then let me never live more.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Then you shall see Sir, I will do a service
That shall deserve indeed.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: 'Tis well said, hunts-man,
And thou shalt be well thought of.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I will do it: 'tis not your letting free, for that's meer nothing,
But such a service, if the Earl be noble,
He shall for ever love me.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What is't hunts-man?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Do you know any of these people live here?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You are a foole then: here be those to have 'em,
I know the Earl so well, would make him caper.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Any of the old Lords that rebel'd?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Peace, all,
I know 'em every one, and can betray 'em.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: But wilt thou doe this service?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: If you'l keep
Your faith, and free word to me.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Wilt thou swear me?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No, no, I will beleeve ye: more then that too,
Here's the right heire.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: O honest, honest hunts-man!

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Now, how to get these Gallants, ther's the matter,
You will be constant, 'tis no work for me else.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Will the Sun shine agen?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: The way to get 'em.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Propound it, and it shall be done.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No sleight;
(For they are Devillish crafty, it concerns 'em,)
Nor reconcilement, (for they dare not trust neither)
Must doe this tricke.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: By force?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I, that must doe it.
And with the person of the Earl himselfe,
Authority (and mighty) must come on 'em:
Or else in vaine: and thus I would have ye do it.
To morrow-night be here: a hundred men will bear 'em,
(So he be there, for he's both wise and valiant)
And with his terrour will strike dead their forces,
The houre be twelve a clock, now for a guide
To draw ye without danger on these persons,
The woods being thicke, and hard to hit, my selfe
With some few with me, made unto our purpose,
Beyond the wood, upon the plain, will wait ye
By the great Oke.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I know it: keep thy faith hunts-man,
And such a showr of wealth—

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I warrant ye:
Misse nothing that I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Farewell;
You have your liberty, now use it wisely;
And keep your houre, goe closer about the wood there,
For feare they spy you.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: And bring no noyse with ye.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.p: All shall be done to'th purpose: farewel hunts-mā. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Gerrard, Higgen, Prig, Ginks, Snap, Ferret.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now, what's the news in towne?

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: No news, but joy Sir;
Every man wooing of the noble Merchant,
Who has his hearty commendations to ye.

sp.speaker: Fer
sp.l: Yes, this is news, this night he's to be married.

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: by'th masse that's true, he marryes Vandoncks daughter
The dainty black-ey'd bell.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I would my clapper
Hung in his baldricke, what a peale could I ring?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Marryed?

sp.speaker: Gin.
sp.l: 'Tis very true Sir, ô the pyes,
The piping-hot mince-pyes.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: O the Plum-pottage.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: For one leg of a goose now would I ventura limb boys,
I love a fat goose, as I love allegiance,
And— upon the Boors, too well they know it,
And therefore starve their powltry.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To be married
To Vandonks daughter?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: O this pretious Merchant:
What sport he will haue? but hark ye brother Prig,
Shall we do nothing in the fore-said wedding?
Ther's money to be got, and meate I take it,
What thinke ye of a morise?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: No, by no meanes,
That goes no further then the street, there leaves us,
Now we must think of something that must draw us
Into the bowels of it, into'th buttery,
Into the Kitchin, into the Cellar, something
That that old drunken Burgo-master loves,
What think ye of a wassell?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I think worthily.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And very fit it should be, thou, and Ferret,
And Ginks to sing the Song: I for the structure,
Which is the bowle.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Which must be up-sey English,
Strong, lusty London beer; let's think more of it,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: He must not marry.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: By your leave in private,
One word Sir, with ye; Gerrard: do not start me,
I know ye, and he knows ye, that best loves ye:
Hubert speakes to ye, and you must be Gerrard,
The time invites you to it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Make no show then,
I am glad to see you Sir; and I am Gerrard.
How stands affaires?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Faire, if ye dare now follow,
Hemskirke I have let goe, and these my causes,
I'le tell ye privately, and how I have wrought him,
And then to prove me honest to my friends,
Looke upon these directions; you have seen his.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Then will I speak a speech, and a brave speech
In praise of Merchants, where's the Ape

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: — Take him,
A gowty Beare-ward stole him the other day.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: May his Beares worry him, that Ape had paid it,
What dainty tricks?— o' that whorson Bear-ward:
In his french doublet, with his baster'd bullions,
In a long stock ty'd up; o how daintily
Would I have made him waite, and change a trencher,
Cary a cup of wine? ten thousand stinks
Waite on thy mangy soule, thou lowzy Bear-ward.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tis passing well, I both beleeve and joy in't
And will be ready; keepe you here the meane while,
And keepe this in, I must a while forsake ye,
Upon mine anger no man stir, this two houres.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Not to the wedding sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Not any whither.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The wedding must be seene sir; we want meat too,
We be monstrous out of meat.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Shall it be spoken,
Fatt Capon shak't their tailes at's in defiance?
And turkey toombs such honorable monuments,
Shall piggs, sir, that the Persons selfe would envy,
And deintie Ducks?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Not a word more, obey me. Exit Ger.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Why then come dolefull death, this is flat tyrany
And by this hand—

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Ile goe sleepe upon't. Exit Hig.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Nay, and there be a wedding, and we wanting
Farewell our happie daies: we doe obey sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 Mer.
sp.l: Well met sir, you are for this lusty wedding.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: I am so, so are you I take it.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: Yes,
And it much glads me, that to doe him service
Who is the honour of our trade, and luster,
We meet thus happily.

sp.speaker: 2. Mer.
sp.l: He's a noble fellow,
And well becomes a bride of such a beauty.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: She is passing faire indeed, long may their loves
Continue like their youths, in spring of sweetnesse,
All the young Merchants will be here
No doubt on't,
For he that comes not to attend this wedding
The curse of a most blind one fall upon him,
A lowd wife, and a lazie: here's Vanlock.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: Well overtaken gentlemen: save ye.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.l: The same to you sir; save ye faire Mistris Francis,
I would this happie night might make you blush too.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: She dreames a pace,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That's but a drowsie fortune.

sp.speaker: 3. Mer.
sp.l: Nay take us with ye too; we come to that end,
I am sure ye are for the wedding.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: Hand and heart man:
And what their feet can doe, I could have tript it
Before this whorson gout

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Blesse ye Masters.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: Clause? how now Clause; thou art come to see thy Master,
(And a good master he is to all poore people)
In all his joy, tis honestly don of thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Long may hee live sir, but my businesse now is
If you would plase to doe it, and to him too.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: He's heere himselfe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Stand at the doore my friends?
I pray walke in: welcome faire Mistris Francis,
See what the house affords, ther's a young Lady
Will bid you welcome,

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: We joy your happinesse. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I hope It will be so: Clause nobly welcome,
My honest, my best friend, I have been carefull
To see thy monys—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sir, that brought not me,
Do you know this Ring againe?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou hadst it of me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And do you well remember yet, the boone you gave me
Upon returne of this?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes, and I grant it,
Be it what it will: aske what thou can'st, I'le do it;
Within my power.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ye are not married yet

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Faith I shall aske you that that will disturb ye,
But I must put ye to your promise.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Do,
And if I faint and flinch in't—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Well said Master,
And yet it grieves me too: and yet it must be.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Prethee distrust me not.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You must not marry,
That's part of the power you gave me: which to make up,
You must presently depart, and follow me.

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.l: Not marry Clause?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Not if you keep your promise,
And give me power to aske.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Pre'thee thinke better,
I will obey, by heaven.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I have thought the best Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Give me thy reason, do'st thou feare her honesty?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Chaste as the yee, for any thing I know, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why should'st thou light on that then? to what purpose?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I must not now discover.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Must not marry?
Shall I breake now when my poore hart is pawn'd?
When all the preparation?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now or never.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Come, 'tis not that thou would'st: thou dost but fright me

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Upon my soule it is Sir, and I binde ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Clause, can'st thou be so cruell?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You may breake Sir,
But never more in my thoughts, appeare honest.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Did'st ever see her?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: No:

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: She is such a thing,
O Clause, she is such a wonder, such a mirror,
For beauty, and faire vertue, Europe has not:
Why hast thou made me happy, to undo me?
But looke upon her; then if thy heart relent not,
I'le quit her presently, who waites there?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Bid my faire love come hither, and the company,
Pre'thee be good unto me; take a mans hart
And looke upon her truly: take a friends hart
And feele what misery must follow this,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Take you a noble hart and keep your promise;
I forsooke all I had, to make you happy.
sp.stage: Enter Bertha. Van-donck, and the rest Merchants.
sp.l: Can that thing call'd a woman, stop your goodnesse?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Looke there she is, deale with me as thou wilt now
Did'st ever see a fayrer?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: She is most goodly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Pray ye stand still.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What ayles my love?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Did'st thou ever,
By the faire light of heaven, behold a sweeter?
O that thou knew'st but love, or ever felt him,
Looke well, looke narrowly upon her beauties.

sp.speaker: 1. Mer.
sp.p: Sure h'as some strange designe in hand, he starts so.

sp.speaker: 2 Mer.
sp.l: This Beggar has a strong power over his pleasure

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: View all her body.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis exact and excellent.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is she a thing then to be lost thus lightly?
Her mind is ten times sweeter, ten times nobler,
And but to heare her speak, a Paradise,
And such a love she beares to me, a chaste love,
A vertuous, faire, and fruitfull love: 'tis now too
I am ready to enjoy it; the Priest ready: Clause,
To say the holy words shall make us happy,
This is a cruelty beyond mans study,
All these are ready, all our joyes are ready,
And all the expectation of our friends,
Twill be her death to do it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Let her dye then.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou canst not: 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It must be.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Twill kil me too, 'twil murder me: by heaven Claus
I'le give thee halfe I have; come thou shalt save me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Then you must goe with me: I can stay no longer
If ye be true, and noble.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Hard heart, I'le follow:
Pray ye all goe in againe, and pray be merry,
I have a weighty businesse, give my cloake there.
Concerns my life, and state; make no enquiry,
This present houre befaln me: with the soonest
I shall be here againe: nay pray goe in Sir,
And take them with you, tis but a night lost, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Come, come in, we will not loose our meat yet,
Nor our good mirth, he cannot stay long from her
I am sure of that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will not stay; beleeve Sir. Exit.
Gertrud, a word with you;

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why is this stop, Sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I have no more time left me, but to kisse thee,
And tell thee this, I am ever thine: farewell wench. Exit.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: And is that all your ceremony? Is this a wedding?
Are all my hopes and prayers turnd to nothing?
Well, I will say no more, nor sigh, nor sorrow; oh me,
Till to thy face I prove thee false. Exit.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: LEad, if thou thinkst we are right: why dost thou make
These often stands? thou saidst thou knewst the way

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: Fear nothing, I doe know it: would twere homeward.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Wrought from me, by a Beggar? at the time
That most should tye him? Tis some other Love
That hath a more command on his affections,
And he that fetcht him, a disguised Agent,
Not what he personated; for his fashion
Was more familiar with him, and more powerfull
Then one that ask'd an almes: I must finde out
One, if not both: kind darknesse be my shrowd
And cover loves too curious search in me,
For yet, suspition, I would not name thee.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Mistris, it grows some-what pretty and dark.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Nay, nothing; do not thinke I am afraid,
Although perhaps you are.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am not, forward.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: Sure but you are: give me your hand, fear nothing.
There's one leg in the wood, do not pull backward:
What a sweate one on's are in, you or I?
Pray God it do not prove the plague; yet sure
It has infected me; for I sweat too,
It runs out at my knees, feele, feele, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What ailes the fellow?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Hark, hark I besech you,
Doe you heare nothing?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Lyst: a wilde hog,
He grunts: now 'tis a beare: this wood is full of 'em,
And now, a wolfe Mistris, a wolfe a wolfe,
It is the howling of a wolfe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: The braying of an asse, is it not.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Oh, now one has me;
Oh, my left ham, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Looke to your shankes,
Your breech is safe enough, the wolfe's a Fern-brake.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: But see, see, see. There is a serpent in it,
It has eyes as broad as platters; it spits fire;
Now it creeps towards us, help me to say my prayers:
It hath swallowed me almost, my breath is stopt,
I cannot speake; do I speake Mistris? tell me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why, thou timerous Sot, canst thou perceive
Any thing i'the bush, but a poore glo-worme?

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: It may be tis but a glo-worm now, but 'twill
Grow to a fire-drake presently.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Come thou from it:
I have a pretious guide of you; and a courteous
That gives me leave to lead my selfe the way thus.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: It thunders, you heare that now.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I heare one hollow.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: 'Tis thunder, thunder:
See, a flash of Lightning:
Are you not blasted Mistris? pull your maske off,
It has plaid the barber with me here: I have lost
My beard, my beard, pray God you be not shaven,
'Twill spoile your marriage Mistris.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What strange wonders,
Feare fancies in a Coward?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Now, the earth opens.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Prethee hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Will you on then?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Both love and jealousie have made me bold,
Where my fate leads me, I must goe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: God be with you then.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: It was the fellow sure, he that should guide me,
The hunts-man that did hollow us.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Best make a stand
And listen to his next: ha?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Mistris, I am taken.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Mistris? look forth souldiers.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: What are you sirha?

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: Truly all is left
Of a poore Boore, by day-light, by night no body,
You might have spar'd your drum, and guns, & pikes too
For I am none that will stand out Sir, I.
You may take me in with a walking sticke
Euen when you please, and hold me with a pack-threed.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What woman was't you call'd to.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Woman? none Sir.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: None? did you not name Mistris?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Yes, but shee's
No woman yet! she should have been this night,
But that a Beggar stole away her Bridegroome,
Whom we were going to make hue and cry after;
I tell you true Sir, she should ha'bin maried to day,
And was the Bride, and all; but in came Clause,
The old lame Beggar, and whips up Mr. Goswin;
Under his arme; away with him as a Kite,
Or an old Fox, would swoope a way a gosling.

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: 'Tis she, 'tis she, 'tis she, Niece?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: She Sir,
This was a noble entrance to your fortune,
That being on the point thus to be married:
Upon her venture here: you should surprise her.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: I begin Hemskirck, to believe my fate,
Works to my ends.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and this adds trust,
Unto the fellow our guide, who assur'd me Floris,
Liv'd in some Merchants shop, as Gerrard did:
I' the old beggars, and that he would use
Him for the traine, to call the other forth,
All which we finde is done— That's he againe— Holla againe

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Good we sent out to meet him.

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: Heer's the Oke.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O I am miserably lost, thus falne
Into my vncles hands from all my hopes,
Can I not thinke away my selfe and dye?
O I am miserably lost; thus fallen
Into my Uncles hands, from all my hopes:
No matter now, where thou be false or no,
Goswin, whether thou love an other better;
Or me alone; or where thou keep thy vow,
And word, or that thou come, or stay: for I
To thee from henceforth, must be ever absent,
And thou to me: no more shall we come neere,
To tell our selves, how bright each other eyes were,
How soft our language, and how sweet our kisses,
Whil'st we made one our food, th' other our feast,
Not mix our soules by sight, or by a letter
Hereafter, but as small relation have,
As two new gon to in habiting a grave:
Can I not thinke away my selfe and dye?

div.stage: Enter Hubert. Higgen. Prig. Ferret. Snap. Gincks. like Boores.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I like your habits well: they are safe, stand close

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: But what's the action we are for now? ha?
Robbing a Ripper of his fish?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Or taking,
A poultrer prisoner, without ransome, Bullyes?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Or cutting off a convoy of butter?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Or surprising a Boores ken, for granting cheates?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Or cackling cheates?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Or mergery-praters, Rogers,
And Tibs o'th the Buttry?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: O' I could drive a Regiment
Of geese afore me, such a night as this
Ten leagues with my hatt, and staff, and not a hisse
Heard, or a wing of my troopes disordered.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Tell us,
If it be milling of a lag of duds,
The fetching of a back of clothes or so;
We are horribly out of linnen.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No such matter.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Let me alone for any Farmers dog,
If you have a minde to the cheese-loft: 'tis but thus:
And he is a silenc'd Mastiff, during pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Would it would please you to be silent.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Mum.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: A friend, the Huntsman.

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: O 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I have kept touch Sir, which is the Earle of these?
Will ye know a man now?

sp.speaker: Hems,
sp.l: This my Lord's the friend,
Hath undertooke the service.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: If 't be worth
His Lordships thanks anon, when 'tis done
Lording, I'le looke for't, a rude woodman,
I know how to pitch my toyles, drive in my game:
And I have don't, both Floriz and his Father
Old Gerrard, with Lord Arnold of Benthuisen,
Cozen, and Jaqueline, young Floris Sister;
I haue 'em all.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Thou speak'st too much, too happy,
To carry faith with it.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I can bring you
Where you shall see, and finde 'em.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: We will double,
What ever Hemskirck then hath promis'd thee.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: And I'le deserve it treble; what horse ha you?

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: A hundred.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: That's well: ready to take
Upon surprise of 'em?

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Devide then,
Your force into five Squadrous; for there are
So many out lets, wayes, thorough the wood,
That issue from the place: where they are lodg'd;
Five severall wayes, of all which passages
We must posses our selves, to round 'em in,
For by one starting hole, they'll all escape else;
I and 4. Boores here, to me will be guides,
The Squadron, where you are, my selfe will lead:
And that they may be more secure, I'le use
My wonted whoopes, and hollowes, as I were
A hunting for 'em; which will make them rest,
Careles of any noyse, and be a direction
To the other guides, how we approch 'em still.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: 'Tis orderd well, and relisheth the Souldier,
Make the division Hemskirck: you are my charge
Faire one, I'le looke to you.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: Shall no body need
To looke to me? I'le looke unto my selfe.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: 'Tis but this, remember.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Say 'tis don boy. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: By this time Sir I hope you want no reasons
Why I broke off your marriage, for though I
Should as a Subject study you my Prince
In things indifferent, it will not therefore
Discredit you, to acknowledge me your Father,
By harkning to my necessary counsells.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Acknowledge you my Father? Sir I do,
And may impiety, conspiring with
My other Sinnes, sinck me, and sodainly
When I forget to pay you a Sonnes duty
In my obedience, and that help'd forth
With all the cheerefullnesse.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I pray you rise,
And may those powers that see and love this in you,
Reward you for it: Taught by your example
Having receiv'd the rights due to a Father,
I tender you th' allegance of a Subject:
Which as my Prince accept of.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Kneele to me?
May mountaines first fall down beneath their valleys,
And fire no more mount upwards, when I suffer
An act in nature so preposterous;
I must o'recome in this, in all things else
The victory be yours: could you here read me,
You should perceive how all my faculties
Triumph in my blest fate, to be found yours;
I am your son, your son Sir, and am prouder
To be so, to the Father, to such goodnesse
(Which heaven be pleas'd, I may inherit from you)
Then I shall ever of those specious titles
That plead for my succession in the Earldome
(Did I possesse it now) left by my mother.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I do beleeve it: but—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O my lov'd Father,
Before I knew you were so, by instinct,
Nature had taught me, to look on your wants,
Not as a strangers: and I know not how,
What you call'd charity, I thought the payment
Of some religious debt, nature stood bound for;
And last of all, when your magnificent bounty
In my low ebb of fortune, had brought in
A flood of blessings, though my threatning wants
And feare of their effects, still kept me stupid,
I soone found out, it was no common pitty
That lead you to it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thinke of this hereafter
When we with joy may call it to remembrance,
There will be a time, more opportune, then now
To end your story, with all circumstances,
I add this only: when we fled from Woolfort
I sent you into England, and there placed you
With a brave Flanders Merchant, call'd rich Goswin,
A man supplyed by me unto that purpose,
As bound by oath never to discover you,
Who dying, left his name and wealth unto you
As his reputed Son, and yet receiv'd so;
But now, is Florez, and a Prince, remember
The countreys, and the subjects generall good
Must challenge the first part in your affection:
The faire maid, whom you chose to be your wife,
Being so far beneath you, that your love
Must grant shee's not your equall.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: In discent
Or borrowed glories, from dead Ancestors,
But for her beauty, chastity, and all vertues
Ever remembred in the best of women,
A Monarch might receive from her, not give,
Though she were his Crownes purchase; In this only
Be an indulgent Father: in all else,
Use my authority.

div.stage: Enter Hubert, Hemskirke, Woolfort, Bertha and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, here be two of 'em,
The Father and the Son, the rest you shall have
As fast as I can rouze them.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Who's this? Woolfort?

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: I Criple, your faigned crutches wil not help you,
Nor patch'd disguise that hath so long conceal'd you,
It's now no halting. I must here finde Gerrard,
And in this Merchants habit, one called Florez
Who would be an Earl.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And is, wert thou a subject.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is this that Traitor Woolfort?

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Yes, but you
Are they that are betraid: Hemskirke;

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My Goswin
Turn'd Prince? ô I am poorer by this greatnesse,
Then all my former jealousies or misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Gertrud?

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Stay Sir, you were to day too neare her,
You must no more ayme at those easy accesses,
Lesse you can do 't in aire, without a head,
Which shall be sodainly tri'de.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O take my heart, first,
And since I cannot hope now to enjoy him,
Let me but fall a part of his glad ransome.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: You know not your own value, that entreat

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So proud a fiend as Woolfort.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: For so lost
A thing as Florez.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: And that would be so
Rather then she should stoop againe to thee;
There is no death, but's sweeter then all life,
When Woolfort is to give it: O my Gertrude,
It is not that, nor Princedom that I goe from,
It is from thee, that losse includeth all.

sp.speaker: Wool
sp.l: I, if my young Prince knew his losse, hee would say so,
Which that he yet may chew on, I will tell him
This is no Gertrude, nor no Hemskirks Niece,
Nor Vandoncks daughter; this is Bertha, Bertha,
The heir of Brabant, she that caus'd the warr,
Whom I did steale, during my treaty there,
For your minority, to raise my selfe;
I then fore-seeing 'twould beget a quarrell.
That, a necessity of my employment,
The same employment, make me master of strength,
That strength, the Lord of Flanders, so of Brabant,
By marrying her: which had not been to doe Sir,
She come of years, but that the expectation
First of her Fathers death, retarded it,
And since the standing out of Bruges, where
Hemskirke had hid her, till she was neer lost:
But Sir, we have recover'd her: your Merchantship
May breake, for this was one of your best bottoms
I thinke

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Insolent Devill!

div.stage: Enter Hubert, with Jaqueline, Gynks and Costin.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Who are these, Hemskirke?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: More, more, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How they triumph in their treachery?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Lord Arnold of Benthusin, this Lord Costin,
This Jaqueline the sister unto Florez.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: All found? why here's brave game, this was sport-royall,
And puts me in thought of a new kind of death for 'em.
Hunts-man, your horn: first wind me Florez fall,
Next Gerrards, then his daughter Jaquelins,
Those rascalls, they shall dye without their rights:
Hang 'em Hemskirke on these trees; Il'e take
The assay of these my selfe.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Not here my Lord,
Let 'em be broken up, upon a scaffold,
Twill shew the better when their arbour's made.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Wretch art thou not content thou hast betraid us
But mocke us too?

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: False Hubert, this is monstrous.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Hubert?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Who, this?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Yes, this is Hubert, Woolfort,
I hope he ha's helpt himselfe to a tree.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: The first,
The first of any, and most glad I have you Sir,
I let you goe before, but for a traine;
Is't you have done this service?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: As your Hunts-man,
But now as Hubert; save your selves, I will,
The Woolf's a foote, let slip; kill, kill, kill, kill.

div.stage: Enter with a drum Van-donck, Merchants, Higgen, Prig, Ferret, Snap.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Betray'd?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No, but well catch'd and I the Huntsman.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: How do you Woolfort? Rascal, good knave Wool:
I speake it now without the Rose, and Hemskirck,
Rogue Hemskirck, you that have no neice, this Lady
Was stolen by you, and tane by you, and now
Resign'd by me, to the right owner here:
Take her my Prince.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Can this be possible,
Welcom my love, my sweet, my worthy love.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: I ha' giv'n you her twice: now keep her better & thanke
Lord Hubert, that came to me in Gerrards name,
And got me out, with my brave Boyes, to march
Like Caesar, when he bred his Comentaryes,
So I, to end my Chronicle, came forth
Caesar Van-donck, & veni, vidi, vici,
Give me my Bottle, and set downe the drum;
You had your tricks Sir, had you? we ha' tricks too,
You stole the Lady?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And we led your Squadrons
Where they ha' scratch'd their leggs a little, with brambles,
If not their faces.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Yes, and run their heads
Against trees.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'Tis Captaine Prig, Sir.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And Coronell Higgen.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: We have fill'd a pitt with your people some with leggs
Some with armes broken, and a neck, or two
I think be loose.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: The rest too, that escap'd,
Are not yet out o'the briars,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And your horses, Sir,
Are well set up in Bruges all by this time:
You looke as you were not well Sir, and would be
Shortly let blood; do you want a scarfe?

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: A halter.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Twas like your selfe, honest, and noble Hubert:
Can'st thou behold these mirrors altogether,
Of thy long, false, and bloody usurpation?
Thy tyrranous proscription, and fresh treason:
And not so see thy selfe, as to fall downe
And sincking, force a grave, with thine owne guilt,
As deep as hell, to couer thee and it?

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: No, I can stand: and praise the toyles that tooke me
And laughing in them dye, they were brave snares.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Twer truer valour, if thou durst repent
The wrongs th' hast don, and live.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Who, I repent?
And say I am sorry? yes, 'tis the fooles language
And not for Woolfort.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Woolfort thou art a Divell,
And speaks his language, oh that I had my longing
Under this rew of trees now would I hang him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No let him live, untill he can repent,
But banish'd from our State, that is thy doome.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Then hang his worthy Captaine here, this Hemskirck
For profit of th' example.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No let him,
Enjoy his shame too: with his conscious life,
To shew how much our innocence contemnes;
All practise from the guiltiest, to molest us.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: A noble prince.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sir, you must helpe to joyne
A paire of hands, as they have don their heartes here,
And to their loves with joy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: As to mine owne,
My gratious Sister, worthiest Brother:

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: I'le go afore, and have the bon-fire made,
My fire-workes, and flap dragons, and good backrack,
With a peck of little fishes, to drink downe
In healthes to this day.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Slight, here be changes,
The Bells ha' not so many, nor a dance, Prig.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Our Company's growne horrible thin by it,
What think you Ferret?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Marry I do thinke,
That we might all be Lords now, if we could stand for't

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Not I if they should offer it: I'le dislodge first,
Remove the Bush to another climat.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sir, you must thanke this worthy Burgomaster,
Here be friends aske to be look'd on too:
And thank'd, who though their trade, and course of life
Be not so perfect, but it may be betterd,
Have yet us'd me with curtesy, and bin true
Subjects unto me, while I was their King,
A place I know not well, how to resigne.
Nor unto whom: But this I will entreat
Your grace, command them, follow me to Bruges;
Where I will take the care on me, to finde
Some manly, and more profitable course
To fit them, as a part of the Republique.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Do you heare Sirs? do so.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Thankes to your good grace.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: To your good Lordship.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: May you both live long.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Attend me at Van-doncks, the Burgomasters. Ex. all but Beggars.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Yes, to beat hemp, and be whipt twice a weeke,
Or turne the wheele, for Crab the Rope-maker:
Or learne to go along with him, his course;
That's a fine course now, i' the Common-wealth, Prig,
What say you to it?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: It is the backwardst course,
I know i'the world.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Then Higgen will scarce thrive by it,
You do conclude?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: 'Faith hardly, very hardly.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Troth I am partly of your minde, Prince Prig.
And therefore farewell Flanders, Higgen will seek
Some safer shelter, in some other Clymat:
With this his tatterd Colony: Let me see
Snap, Ferret, Prig, and Higgen, all are left
O the true blood: what? shall we into England?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Agreed,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Then beare up bravely with your Brute my lads
Higgen hath prig'd the prancers in his dayes,
And sold good peny-worthes; we will have a course,
The spirit of Bottom, is growne bottomlesse.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: I'le mand no more, nor cant.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Yes, your sixpenyworth
In private, brother, sixpence is a summ,
I'le steale you any mans dogg for

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: For Sixpence more,
You'l tell the owner where he is.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Tis right,
Higgen must practise, so must Prig to eat;
And write the Letter: and gi' the word, But now
No more, as either of these.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: But as true Beggars,
As ere we were.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: We stand here, for an Epilogue;
Ladyes, your bountyes first; the rest will follow,
For womens favours, are a leading almes,
If you be pleas'd look cheerely throw your eyes:
Out at your maskes.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And let your beauties sparkle.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: So may you neer want dressings, Iewells, gownes
Still i' the fashion.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Nor the men you love,
Wealth nor discourse to please you.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: May you Gentlemen,
Never want good fresh suites nor liberty.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: May every Merchant here see safe his ventures.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And every honest Citizen his debts in.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: The Lawyers gaine good Clyents.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And the Clyents good Councell.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: All the Gamesters here good fortune.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The Drunkards too good wine.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: The eaters meate
Fit for their tasts and pallats.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The good wives kind Husbands.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: The young maides choyce of Sutors.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The Midwives merry hearts.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And all good cheere.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: As you are kinde unto us and our Bush,
We are the Beggars and your dayly Beadsmen,
And have your money, but the Almes we aske
And live by, is your Grace, give that and then
W'eel boldly say our word is, Come agen.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
